data.title: When bowling balls take out people, not pins
authors: Vicki Prevost Pin Tales, New Bedford Standard-Times
data.meta_description: Who says you can’t get seriously hurt bowling, or just walking in a bowling center? \n I know I’m not the first person to have this happen, nor will I be the last person, but I want to bring awareness…
data.text:
Who says you can’t get seriously hurt bowling, or just walking in a bowling center?

I know I’m not the first person to have this happen, nor will I be the last person, but I want to bring awareness to it so that it doesn’t happen again.

A bowling ball or balls in bowling bags look harmless enough, even three bowling bags sitting on the floor in a row don’t look that menacing, but believe me when I tell you that they can cause injury to an unaware person.

Last Sunday at AMF Somerset Lanes just prior to the 12:30 p.m. team squad in the Southeastern Mass. USBC Bowling Association’s annual Championship Tournament, myself and Gayle Koczera were selling 50/50 raffle tickets to benefit the association’s scholarship fund.

I turned around and started to walk further down the concourse to sell more tickets. Unfortunately, I didn’t look down and my feet hit something solid, very solid.

In what seemed like slow motion (according to Koczera, it also looked like slow motion), I fell stomach-down across three, three-ball bowling bags. It was not a soft landing.

When I was coming down, my face was very close to a chair and noticing that, I bent my head back. When I hit the bowling bags, my legs bent up backwards so that my back was in a “U” position. Not a pretty picture, nor did it feel so pretty.

With blood running from my lip as a result of biting it during the fall, I laid there momentarily dazed. My back hurt, not just a little — it hurt a lot. You could say that I was bowled over.

I thought, "Oh no, this is pretty serious."

With help from Koczera and others, I was lifted up into a chair and received some ice for my lip.

Fortunately for me, my daughter, Cheryl Dubord, who lives in New Hampshire, was visiting me for the weekend and she is a 911 dispatcher. She was immediately summoned and took over in 911-mode asking me all kinds of questions. She claims she was more in daughter-mode.

“Did you lose consciousness?” she asked me first. I replied no. She went on to ask where I hurt? Do I feel light headed? And a host of other questions that escape me now, and I also can’t remember my answers.

“I think that if I weren’t there,” my daughter said, “I probably would have never heard about her accident. Mothers!”

Cheryl made sure that she notified AMF Somerset Lanes’ management so an incident report could be filed. AMF headquarters upper management called me the next day to follow-up on the report.

I left my car in their parking lot and Cheryl (after I uncomfortably sat around for a while contemplating whether or not I should be examined) took me to the emergency room at St. Luke’s Hospital in New Bedford.

After telling numerous people at the ER what happened (everyone there assumed I fell while bowling), I finally was wheeled into an X-ray room and had my back X-rayed.

Nothing was broken (thank God), but I was told that I would probably be in pain for quite a while. I was given prescriptions for pain medication and a muscle relaxant and was told to apply heat to my back periodically.

Unfortunately, my bowling is curtailed for now. I couldn’t bowl my doubles and singles squad later that day and I thank Kim Amaral for taking my place so that Koczera wouldn’t have to go without a doubles partner.

The point to this painful story is to always watch where you are walking in a bowling center. Bowling balls are often left in places where they shouldn’t be, especially when there is a tournament and many bowlers who have more than one ball, and even more than one bag are gathered.

Also, if you are in command of a bowling ball or balls, please consider where you place them in proximity to open walkways so they won’t be in pedestrian’s paths.

I don’t know how long I’ll be sidelined, but I am going to a chiropractor for treatment. Hopefully it won’t be too long.

I do know I will always look down when walking in a bowling center from now on. Bowling balls, by design, are supposed to knock down pins, not people.

Upcoming events

A Bowl for the Cure Tournament (the second-annual Singles Handicap Bowling Tournament) is March 26 at Holiday Lanes in Westport at 4 p.m. Entry fee is $40 per bowler. Handicap is 90 percent of 240 and the format is four games across eight lanes. Mail early entries to Norm Blanchette, 17 Grand Pine Way, Westport, MA 02790.

The 53rd Massachusetts USBC Women’s Bowling Association’s annual Championships is April 23-24, April 30-May 1 and May 7-8 at Ken’s Bowl in Pittsfield. Entries close on April 1. Entry forms are available at all local tenpin centers.

The 57th annual Massachusetts State USBC Bowling Association’s Championship Tournament is April 23-24, April 30-May 1, May-7-8 and 14-15 at Greylock Bowl and Golf in North Adams. Entries close on April 9, but walk-ins are welcome based on lane availability. Entry forms are available at each local tenpin center.

Highlights

Amy Robinson, in the Westport Trios at Holiday Lanes in Westport, bowled a 753 series that included 278 and 248 games.

David Saucier in the Westport Trios at Holiday Lanes in Westport bowled an 806 series that included a 300 game.

Jon Norton, in the Center League at Wonder Bowl, bowled an 804 series that included 258, 289 and 257 games.

Ryan Conterno, in the Splice Girls Mixed League at Wonder Bowl, bowled a 300 game on Feb. 22.

Jason Lopes Jr., in the A.M. Junior Program at Wonder Bowl, bowled a triplicate 215.

Noah Carroll, in the Next Generation Junior League at Wonder Bowl, bowled a 747 series that included 253 and 289 games.

Cole Szczupak, in the Twilight League at Wonder Bowl, bowled a 300 game on March 11.

Shane Lavoie, in the Westport Trios League at Holiday Lanes in Westport, bowled a 300 game on March 7.

Tommy Machado, in the Center League at Wonder Bowl, bowled a 300 game on March 9.

Alex Aguiar was third in a NEBA Singles event at AMF Circle Lanes in East Haven, Conn. on March 6.

Southeastern Mass. USBC Youth Association Bowlers of the Month for February were: seniors, Noah Carroll, 747, Wonder Bowl and Mckenzie Childs, 554, Wonder Bowl, juniors, Coltin Baptiste, 609, Wonder Bowl and Hailey Gauthier, 440, Wonder Bowl, preps, Aiden Cardoza, 497, Wonder Bowl and Rachel Enos, 448, Wonder Bowl and bantams, Xavier Geliga, 380, Wonder Bowl and Serena Whenal, 261, Wonder Bowl.

In a press release from USBC dated March 15, they state that the USBC has revoked the approval of two Motiv brand bowling balls and removed them from the list of balls approved for competition effective March 15. The Motiv Jackal and the Jackal Carnage balls do not comply with current specifications and requirements in the USBC Equipment Specifications and Certifications Manual. For further information on the revocation of these two bowling balls, visit Bowl.com.
